channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Plans Evacuations in Kherson and Mykolaiv
item.description: The government is making plans to evacuate residents who want to leave from Kherson and Mykolaiv, where fighting has badly damaged the infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians in Kherson gathering for food aid on Saturday.

item.title: Videos Suggest Captive Russian Soldiers Were Killed at Close Range
item.description: Videos circulating online and reported on by Russian state media have raised questions about whether Ukrainian soldiers committed a war crime.
item.dc:creator: Malachy Browne, Stephen Hiltner, Chevaz Clarke-Williams and Taylor Turner
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Turkey Bombs Kurdish Foes in Iraq and Syria, Likely Killing Dozens
item.description: Turkish officials said the airstrikes were a counterterrorism operation against militants it accused of bombing Istanbul last week.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Sangar Khaleel
item.media:description: Damage by Turkish airstrikes on Sunday in the Syrian village of Taql Baql, in Hasakeh Province.

item.title: Inmates Who Killed a Writer and a Publisher Escape in Bangladesh
item.description: Men convicted of fatally stabbing the Bangladeshi-American author Avijit Roy and his publisher fled custody in an unsettling reminder of extremist violence against intellectuals.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Zakir Hossain Chowdhury/NurPhoto via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mourning Avijit Roy in 2019 in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Mr. Roy, an author critical of religious extremism, was hacked to death by assailants with machetes as he left a book fair in 2015.

item.title: In Iraq’s Mountains, Iranian Opposition Fighters Feel the Squeeze
item.description: The armed groups, which have trained in the Kurdistan region for decades, face attacks from Iran and pressure from the Iraqi government to give up their weapons.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Sangar Khaleel and Emily Garthwaite

item.title: Malaysian Election Adds New Turmoil: Hung Parliament
item.description: The country has been hit by a series of political shocks in recent years and now confronts the first hung Parliament in its history.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Lining up to vote in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Saturday. The government lowered the voting age in 2019, and a record number of voters cast ballots.

item.title: U.N. Climate Talks End With a Deal to Pay Poor Nations for Damage
item.description: Nations reached a landmark deal to compensate developing nations for climate harm. But some leaders said the summit didn’t go far enough in addressing the root causes of global warming.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, Max Bearak, Lisa Friedman and Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Sameh Shoukry, the Egyptian foreign minister, seated, reading a statement at the closing session of climate talks in Sharm el Sheikh.

item.title: Gang Violence Cripples Haiti’s Fight Against Cholera
item.description: The disease is spreading in the Caribbean nation in part because armed groups control poor neighborhoods with ruthless violence and prevent doctors from providing basic care.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Adriana Zehbrauskas
item.media:description: People displaced by violence in their neighborhoods living at a public park in Port-au-Prince, the capital of Haiti.

item.title: As Climate Protests Get Bolder, British Police Strike Back With New Powers
item.description: New rules curtailing protests have alarmed some who fear an erosion of civil rights. They come as environmental protesters have intensified their tactics to draw attention to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Activists from the group Just Stop Oil being arrested last month for blocking a road in London.

item.title: Red Sea Coral Reefs Keep Thriving Despite Global Warming
item.description: As warming waters devastate coral around the world, the sea’s stunningly colorful reefs have been remarkably resilient. But pollution, mass tourism and overfishing put them at risk.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Sima Diab for The New York Times
item.media:description: Corals in the waters of the Ras Mohammed National Park in the Red Sea near Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, home to one of the only reefs in the world that can tolerate heat.

item.title: World Cup in Qatar Caps Big Gulf Push Into International Sports
item.description: In hosting major international sporting events, buying up soccer teams and even creating a golf league, the resource-rich Gulf States are seeking attention, prestige, economic diversification and political credibility.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Images of soccer players adorned skyscrapers on Thursday in Doha, Qatar.

item.title: In Yahidne, Ukraine, a Battered School Holds Memories of Trauma
item.description: In Yahidne, a village in northern Ukraine, a basement became a virtual prison for hundreds of residents for four weeks. Months later, that horror lingers.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahidne last month. In March, more than 300 residents, including 77 children, were marched from their homes at gunpoint and forced into a cramped school basement.

item.title: Security Forces in Iran Have Blinded Hundreds of Protesters
item.description: Security forces have been firing ammunition that has ruptured the eyes of antigovernment demonstrators in the past two months. “Everything went dark,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Saman, an Iranian protester who was blinded in one eye by a rubber bullet before fleeing the country, in an undisclosed location this month. He is one of hundreds of victims of severe eye injuries inflicted by Iranian security forces.

item.title: Would You Pay $1,000 to See the World’s Biggest Lizards?
item.description: Indonesia wants to make it vastly more expensive to see the country’s famous Komodo dragons. The local tourism industry is up in arms.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:description: One of the many Komodo dragons that roam free in Komodo National Park in Indonesia.

item.title: Inside the Saudi Strategy to Keep the World Hooked on Oil
item.description: The kingdom is working to keep fossil fuels at the center of the world economy for decades to come by lobbying, funding research and using its diplomatic muscle to obstruct climate action.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Iman Al-Dabbagh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A solar farm at the King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center in Riyadh, the Saudi capital.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A nightclub shooting in Colorado kills five.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: There did not appear to be any prior threats to Club Q before the shooting, the Colorado Springs police chief said on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The World Cup Kicks Off
item.description: Plus COP27 ends with a landmark deal and Twitter reinstates Donald Trump’s account.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Ecuador’s Enner Valencia celebrated scoring their second goal with teammates at Al Bayt Stadium in Al Khor, Qatar, on Sunday.

item.title: Canada Imposes Sanctions on Haiti’s Former Leader and Other Officials
item.description: Among the six targeted over possible ties to criminal gangs were former President Michel Martelly and two former prime ministers.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Haitian police officers at a checkpoint in a gang-controlled area of Port-au-Prince, the capital, last year.

item.title: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Endures More Shelling
item.description: The United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency called the strikes “extremely disturbing.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant last month.

item.title: At Least 437 Children Have Been Killed Since February, Ukraine says.
item.description: Andriy Kostin, Ukraine’s prosecutor general, said that the true numbers were likely to be far higher.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The aftermath of a deadly Russian missile attack in Vinnytsia, Ukraine, in July.

item.title: A Contentious World Cup
item.description: Concerns about corruption and human rights loom over a typically joyous sporting event.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Doha, Qatar.

item.title: At Least 5 Dead and 25 Injured in Gunman’s Rampage at an L.G.B.T.Q. Club in Colorado
item.description: The police said a suspect in the shooting, who was also injured, was arrested.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Mitch Smith, Adam Goldman and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Andrew Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evidence markers outside a 7-Eleven store near Club Q in Colorado Springs.

item.title: Fireball Flashes Above Ontario and Parts of the U.S.
item.description: The bright meteor was the sixth object detected in space before striking Earth, the European Space Agency said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: It’s Official: The Leap Second Will Be Retired (a Decade from Now)
item.description: On Friday, an international vote was taken to ditch the leap second, a technical fudge that has caused headaches since its inception 50 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Alanna Mitchell
item.category: International Bureau of Weights and Measures
National Institute of Standards and Technology
item.media:description: Clock faces at the Electric Time Company in Medfield, Mass. The leap second was devised as a way to align the atomic time scale, in use since 1967 and derived from the vibration of cesium atoms, with the slightly slower time kept by Earth as it rotates.

item.title: As the War Rages, Ukraine Wages a Daunting Battle to Rebuild
item.description: Fully 61,000 square miles could be littered with land mines and other explosives left by retreating Russian forces, while half the electric grid has been destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sapper from the Kyiv Regional Emergency Services placed an artillery shell cleared from a former Russian encampment on Wednesday in Myrotske, Ukraine.

item.title: In a First, Rich Countries Agree to Pay for Climate Damages in Poor Nations
item.description: After 30 years of deadlock, a new U.N. climate agreement aims to pay developing countries for loss and damage caused by global warming. But huge questions remain about how it would work.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, Lisa Friedman, Max Bearak and Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Climate activists at a protest on Saturday at the COP27 climate summit in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt.

item.title: Pie, Made Easy
item.description: Stressed about a homemade Thanksgiving pie? Don’t be. My tips will help.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Ko

item.title: Did Billions in Spending Make a Dent in Homelessness? Canada Doesn’t Know.
item.description: An auditor general’s report found that multibillion-dollar federal housing programs were not being tracked to see whether they actually reduced homelessness.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Tents at a homeless encampment at a park in Vancouver last winter as an arctic front hit Canada’s western provinces.

item.title: With nearly half of Ukraine’s energy grid knocked out, Zelensky says 17 regions face a ‘difficult situation.’
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage to a high-voltage electrical substation in Ukraine caused by a Russian missile strike in October.

item.title: 1st Train in 9 Months Leaves Kyiv for Kherson
item.description: A train, carrying 200 passengers, made the 11-hour journey for the first time since Ukraine retook the city, a senior official said.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oksana Shevluga, 51, and her daughter, Anastasia, 30, embrace as they see each other for the first time in months. Anastasia had arrived on Saturday on the first train from Kyiv to Kherson since the invasion.

item.title: Kim Jong-un Takes His Daughter to Missile Test Launch
item.description: Little is known about North Korea’s ruling family. Yesterday was the first public appearance of the child, who is thought to be named Ju-ae.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, with his daughter at the launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile on Friday.

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 19, 2022
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 19, 2022.

item.title: Iranian Protesters Attack Khomeini’s Childhood Home as Unrest Spreads
item.description: The house where the Islamic revolution’s founder grew up was set on fire during a fresh surge of anger over the government’s killing of children, including three in the city of Izeh.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Russia Raises Hopes for Griner’s Release, but U.S. Says It’s Just Talk
item.description: The State Department says Russia refuses to negotiate seriously to free the basketball star Brittney Griner, who was sent to a penal colony with a nine-year sentence on a cannabis charge.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: The American basketball player Brittney Griner, right, being escorted to a hearing at the Khimki City Court outside Moscow in August.

item.title: Oil Prices Slide as Investors Worry Energy Demand Is Slowing
item.description: The U.S. benchmark oil price fell to about $80 a barrel on Friday, and gasoline prices in some states are now close to $3 a gallon.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Slowing economic growth is pushing down the use and price of oil and petroleum products.

item.title: Rishi Sunak, With Elite Pedigree, Must Now Sell Britain on Austerity
item.description: The country’s new prime minister must now persuade ordinary Britons that they should support his government through a painful ordeal of tax increases, spending cuts and a recession.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain departing 10 Downing Street last week to face questions before Parliament.

item.title: COP27 Climate Talks Spill Over as Nations Debate Loss and Damage Funding
item.description: Debate intensified over a contentious issue: the creation of a fund to help poor and vulnerable countries pay for loss and damage caused by climate change.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Protests outside the United Nations climate summit in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, on Friday.

item.title: Deadly Blaze in Gaza Strip Kills 21 People Gathered for a Family Party
item.description: The fast-moving blaze and the high number of deaths led to accusations that emergency units were too slow in responding.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguishing flames in the apartment that was ravaged by fire on Thursday. The blaze was one of the deadliest disasters in Gaza in recent memory not connected to the violence from the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

item.title: Griner Enters a Penal Colony, Russia Signals Openness to Prisoner Swap
item.description: Russia reiterated its openness to a prisoner exchange with the United States involving the notorious convicted arms dealer Viktor Bout. The State Department says Russia refuses to negotiate in good faith.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Brittney Griner before a court hearing in August.

item.title: A Beloved Show Gets Another Life
item.description: The unexpected revival of “Neighbours,” the long-running drama that offered a sweet, uncontroversial vision of Australia, comes via Amazon. Will streaming change its nature?
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Taking on the Climate
item.description: International climate summits are imperfect, but they have led to real progress.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: COP27 climate conference in Egypt.

item.title: Anton Filatov, Ukrainian Film Critic, Drafted Into Real-Life War
item.description: Anton Filatov, a Ukrainian film critic, was pulled into a theater he never expected to enter: the front lines of war, where he now writes of the scene in the trenches instead of what’s onscreen.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anton Filatov, left, a Ukrainian film critic turned soldier, in an abandoned house near the front in Donbas in August. He has kept writing throughout the war, though his subject has changed.

item.title: In France, Victims’ Fund Struggles to Heal Terrorism’s Traumas
item.description: At the trial over the 2016 terrorist attack in Nice, bereaved family members and survivors vent frustration at a cumbersome process to obtain compensation.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial in 2016 for a terrorist attack in Nice, France. The trial, which is continuing, is intended to bring the victims a measure of comfort, clarity and catharsis.

item.title: The End of Covid Vaccines at ‘Warp Speed’
item.description: Financial and bureaucratic barriers in the United States mean that the next generation of Covid vaccines may well be designed here, but used elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: While government funding helped to protect pharmaceutical companies in 2020 from the downsides of spending heavily on tricky vaccine research, there are no such assurances in 2022.

item.title: US Backs Immunity for Saudi Leader in Lawsuit Over Khashoggi Murder
item.description: The State Department said Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom’s de facto ruler, should have legal immunity as the head of the Saudi government.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Biden meeting with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Saudi Arabia in July. The visit was seen as a sign of a thaw between the two leaders.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Three men have been found guilty of the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 and the murder of the 298 people onboard.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Anton Kotte, left, who lost his son, daughter-in-law and grandson in the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, hugs Piet Ploeg, whose brother, sister-in-law and nephew were killed, hug each other at the Schiphol Judicial Complex after the verdict on Thursday.

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 18, 2022
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 18, 2022.

item.title: North Korea Launches Another ICBM, One of Its Most Powerful Yet
item.description: It was the latest in a series of increasingly provocative weapons tests in recent weeks, and drew condemnation from Japan and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Motoko Rich
item.media:description: News coverage of North Korea’s latest missile launch in Tokyo on Friday.

item.title: 21 Killed in Fast-Moving Gaza Fire in Jabaliya Neighborhood
item.description: A family celebration turned deadly, and officials said that gasoline stored in an apartment fueled the fire and contributed to the high death toll.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: An apartment house was ravaged by fire in the Jabaliya neighborhood in the northern Gaza Strip on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: MH17 Convictions
item.description: Plus, Nancy Pelosi leaves leadership and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A Dutch court on Thursday delivered its verdict in a the shooting down of a Malaysia Airlines passenger jet over eastern Ukraine in 2014, which killed all 298 people aboard.

item.title: The Surprising Afterlife of Unwanted Atom Bombs
item.description: The Biden administration has called for the retirement of the B83 superweapon, but nuclear experts say its most destructive parts will live on indefinitely in one form or another.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Retired nuclear weapons being readied for disassembly at the government’s Pantex plant near Amarillo, Texas, in 1996.

item.title: Dutch Court Convicts 3 of Murder for 2014 Downing of Flight MH17 in Ukraine
item.description: The victim’s families drew some solace from the verdict, which placed responsibility for the tragedy squarely with Moscow, but the men found guilty may never be arrested.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The verdict session of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 trial near Amsterdam, on Thursday.

item.title: Brittney Griner Transferred to Russian Penal Colony, Lawyers Say
item.description: The W.N.B.A. star, who has been detained in Russia since February, is facing nine years in a Russian prison on a drug charge.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, the U.S. basketball star, being escorted to court in August in Khimki, Russia.

item.title: Alaa Abd El Fattah, Egyptian Political Prisoner, Had Near-Death Experience, Family Says
item.description: Alaa Abd El Fattah, who is being given nutrients intravenously, told his relatives he collapsed in prison but planned to resume his hunger strike again.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest for Alaa Abd El Fattah in front of the British Embassy in Rome this month.

item.title: Lab-Grown Meat Receives Clearance From F.D.A.
item.description: In a first step toward cultivated meat reaching dinner tables and restaurant menus, regulators said that a start-up company’s chicken was safe to eat.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Gabriela Hasbun for The New York Times
item.media:description: A chicken dish featuring lab-grown meat from Upside Foods, the company whose product received regulatory clearance.

item.title: What to Know As UK Unveils Budget Proposal
item.description: The government’s budget proposal, known as the Autumn Statement, will lead to £55 billion in tax rises and spending cuts to fill a massive funding gap. Here are five takeaways.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The budget proposal comes as Britain is experiencing the highest surge in consumer prices in more than four decades.

item.title: Meet the ‘Closer’ Who Finds the Right Words When Climate Talks Hit a Wall
item.description: Sue Biniaz is considered one of the most innovative American legal minds when it comes to climate negotiations. She once rescued a collapsing deal by using quotation marks.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Frances F. Denny for The New York Times

item.title: Alexei Navalny Says He Has Been Placed in Permanent Solitary Confinement
item.description: The Russian opposition leader has been jailed since March 2021 after surviving an assassination attempt that American intelligence agencies blamed on Russian security agents.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Alina Lobzina and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Aleksei Navalny in court in Moscow last year.
